passage:
(1) The Great Barrier Reef, stretching over 2,300 kilometers along Australia's northeastern coast, stands as the world's largest coral reef ecosystem and one of the most diverse natural wonders on our planet. This magnificent living structure is composed of nearly 3,000 individual reefs and 900 islands, forming a complex mosaic of marine habitats that supports an extraordinary variety of life. The reef was formed gradually over millions of years as generations of tiny coral polyps built upon the skeletal remains of their predecessors, creating the massive calcium carbonate structure we see today.

(2) Home to over 1,500 species of fish, 400 types of coral, 4,000 varieties of mollusks, and countless other marine organisms, the Great Barrier Reef represents a pinnacle of biodiversity. Its waters host endangered species such as the dugong (sea cow) and various sea turtles, while also serving as a breeding ground for humpback whales that migrate from Antarctica. The reef's ecological complexity creates numerous specialized habitats—from shallow intertidal zones to deep oceanic trenches—each supporting distinct communities of organisms that have evolved intricate relationships over thousands of years.

(3) Despite its status as a UNESCO World Heritage site and its protection under Australia's Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, this natural wonder faces unprecedented threats. Climate change remains the most significant challenge, as rising ocean temperatures have triggered several mass coral bleaching events since the late 1990s. When water temperatures exceed corals' tolerance thresholds, they expel the symbiotic algae living in their tissues, causing them to turn white and potentially die if conditions don't improve quickly. Additionally, ocean acidification, resulting from increased absorption of atmospheric carbon dioxide, weakens coral structures by making it more difficult for corals to extract calcium carbonate from seawater.

(4) Human activities closer to shore compound these global threats. Agricultural runoff introduces excess nutrients and pesticides into reef waters, promoting algal growth that competes with corals for space and light. Coastal development, including port expansions and dredging, increases sedimentation that can smother coral polyps and reduce the sunlight reaching them. Overfishing disrupts the delicate balance of reef ecosystems, especially when key species that control algal growth are removed. Even tourism, while economically valuable and raising awareness about conservation, can cause damage through boat anchors, sunscreen chemicals, and physical contact with fragile coral formations.

(5) Conservation efforts to protect the Great Barrier Reef have intensified in recent years, adopting a multi-faceted approach that addresses both local and global threats. The Australian government has implemented stricter regulations on agricultural practices in watershed areas and has expanded no-take zones where fishing is prohibited. Innovative restoration techniques, including coral nurseries where resilient coral species are cultivated and then transplanted to damaged areas, show promise for reef recovery. Scientists are also investigating methods to enhance coral resilience through selective breeding and assisted evolution. Perhaps most importantly, there is growing recognition that saving the Great Barrier Reef ultimately depends on addressing climate change through global reductions in greenhouse gas emissions—a challenge that requires unprecedented international cooperation.

questions.question: This time tomorrow, I _____ for my final exam.
The tour guide recommended _____ at the historical monument to appreciate its architecture.

questions.question: We need to buy _____ new furniture for _____ living room in our apartment.
When the fire alarm _____, most of the employees _____ in the cafeteria.
By the time we arrive at the theater, the movie _____.
The company made a significant _____ to reduce carbon emissions last year.
Sarah said she _____ to the conference the following week.
Look at those dark clouds! It _____ rain soon.
She bought a _____ at the antique store yesterday.
_____ I borrow your calculator for the exam tomorrow?
If I had learned to play an instrument as a child, I _____ in the orchestra now.
You _____ submit your application by Friday; otherwise, it won't be considered.
By next month, the new shopping center _____.
The negotiations reached a _____ point when neither side was willing to compromise.
Please _____ in mind that the deadline for applications is next Friday.
The company decided to _____ down operations during the economic downturn.
She managed to _____ up with an excellent solution to the problem.
The government has introduced new measures to _____ with climate change.
After the accident, it took him months to _____ a full recovery.
The professor _____ emphasis on the importance of critical thinking.
They decided to _____ advantage of the good weather and went hiking.
The presentation didn't quite _____ up to everyone's expectations.
The charity has _____ a difference in the lives of thousands of children.
The professor's explanation was so _____ that few students understood it.
Her _____ remarks at the meeting offended several colleagues.
The company is looking for a(n) _____ solution to reduce its carbon footprint.
The documentary provided a _____ account of the historical events.
The medicine helped to _____ the pain, but didn't eliminate it completely.
The politician's speech was full of _____ statements that couldn't be verified.
After the scandal, his reputation was _____ beyond repair.
She has a(n) _____ memory and can recall events from decades ago in great detail.
The company's profits have _____ over the past three years.
The negotiations were _____ by unexpected legal complications.
The two theories are _____ and cannot both be correct.
Many historical buildings have been _____ to their former glory through careful restoration.
Despite her _____ schedule, she always finds time to volunteer at the shelter.
The company's _____ approach to innovation has resulted in several groundbreaking products.
The government introduced _____ measures to prevent the spread of the disease.
According to the passage, the Great Barrier Reef was formed by:

options.A: Volcanic activity over thousands of years
options.B: Tectonic plate movement along Australia's coast
options.C: Generations of coral polyps building upon skeletal remains

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as an organism found in the Great Barrier Reef?
The passage indicates that coral bleaching occurs when:

options.C: Corals expel symbiotic algae due to high water temperatures
options.D: Sediment from coastal development smothers coral polyps

questions.question: Based on the passage, which threat to the Great Barrier Reef is described as the most significant?
Which conservation approach is NOT mentioned in the passage?

options.B: Creating no-take zones where fishing is prohibited
options.C: Cultivating resilient coral species in nurseries
options.D: Implementing stricter regulations on agricultural practices

questions.question: The passage suggests that ocean acidification affects corals by:

options.B: Making it harder for them to extract calcium carbonate
options.D: Reducing the amount of sunlight they receive

questions.question: According to the passage, which of the following is a reason why agricultural runoff threatens the reef?

options.A: It introduces toxins that directly kill coral polyps
options.B: It reduces water clarity and prevents photosynthesis
options.C: It promotes algal growth that competes with corals
options.D: It causes immediate coral bleaching events

questions.question: The author's tone in discussing conservation efforts in paragraph 5 could best be described as:
Which statement best summarizes the main idea of the passage?

options.A: The Great Barrier Reef's biodiversity makes it the world's most important marine ecosystem
options.B: Climate change is destroying the Great Barrier Reef despite conservation efforts
options.C: The Great Barrier Reef faces numerous threats but conservation efforts are being implemented
options.D: Australia's economy depends on protecting the Great Barrier Reef tourism industry

questions.question: The passage implies that saving the Great Barrier Reef ultimately requires:

options.C: International cooperation to address climate change
options.D: Banning tourism in sensitive reef areas
